articles.headline: A Hand-to-Hand Struggle With a Raging River
articles.snippet: In an age of technology, communities along the Mississippi still rely on the basics: shovel sand in bag, pray it works.
articles.abstract: In an age of technology, communities along the Mississippi still rely on the basics: shovel sand in bag, pray it works.

articles.headline: Audit Says Tanker Deal Is Flawed
articles.snippet: The Air Force made errors in awarding a lucrative contract to Northrop Grumman and its European partner, the Government Accountability Office said.
articles.abstract: The Air Force made errors in awarding a lucrative contract to Northrop Grumman and its European partner, the Government Accountability Office said.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a stunning turnabout for the Boeing Company, government auditors on Wednesday upheld the company’s appeal of the Air Force’s decision to award a $35 billion contract to build midair refueling tankers to a partnership of Northrop Grumman and the European parent of Airbus.

articles.headline: Fallout From Bad Loans Rocks Regional Banks
articles.snippet: Regional banks across the nation are being shaken to the core by the mortgage crisis. For many of them, things are going from bad to worse.
articles.abstract: Regional banks across the nation are being shaken to the core by the mortgage crisis. For many of them, things are going from bad to worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Ohio, the Panic of 1907 drove the Fifth National Bank into the arms of the Third National Bank, creating the singularly named Fifth Third Bank of Cincinnati.

articles.headline: The Catch Phrase Is ‘à La Carte’ as Airlines Push Additional Fees
articles.snippet: Airlines are adding fees and surcharges on top of rising fares. They would like travelers to embrace them as “à la carte pricing.”
articles.abstract: Airlines are adding fees and surcharges on top of rising fares. They would like travelers to embrace them as “à la carte pricing.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Airlines are adding fees and surcharges on top of rising fares. They would like travelers to embrace them as “à la carte pricing.”

articles.headline: Obama’s Campaign Tightens Control of Image and Access
articles.snippet: Barack Obama’s strategists are taking extra steps to protect against attacks, but such efforts at times appear to conflict with the senator’s stated desire for openness.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama’s strategists are taking extra steps to protect against attacks, but such efforts at times appear to conflict with the senator’s stated desire for openness.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a rally for Senator Barack Obama in Detroit on Monday, two Muslim women said they were prohibited from sitting behind the candidate because they were wearing head scarves and campaign volunteers did not want them to appear with him in news photographs or live television coverage.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Dearth of Ships Delays Drilling of Offshore Oil
articles.snippet: As President Bush considers repealing a ban on offshore drilling, a shortage of ships used for such drilling promises to impede any rapid increase in oil supply.
articles.abstract: As President Bush considers repealing a ban on offshore drilling, a shortage of ships used for such drilling promises to impede any rapid increase in oil supply.
articles.lead_paragraph: As President Bush calls for repealing a ban on drilling off most of the coast of the United States, a shortage of ships used for deep-water offshore drilling promises to impede any rapid turnaround in oil exploration and supply.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Martin Fackler

articles.headline: Grocery Shopping Made Easy
articles.snippet: Meet the Ikan, a scanning device that allows you to stay home and order groceries from an illustrated, error-proof shopping list.
articles.abstract: Meet the Ikan, a scanning device that allows you to stay home and order groceries from an illustrated, error-proof shopping list.
articles.lead_paragraph: On “The Jetsons,” when George got hungry, he just pushed a couple of buttons on the Food-a-Rac-a-Cycle on the kitchen counter. In seconds, a freshly synthesized meal appeared on a plate, prepared to his exact specifications.

articles.headline: An Unlikely Antagonist in the Detainees’ Corner
articles.snippet: Lt. Cmdr. William C. Kuebler is the latest example of a lawyer in uniform attacking the Pentagon’s legal system.
articles.abstract: Lt. Cmdr. William C. Kuebler is the latest example of a lawyer in uniform attacking the Pentagon’s legal system.
articles.lead_paragraph: When he speaks publicly, Lt. Cmdr. William C. Kuebler, a military lawyer for a Guantánamo detainee, is careful to say his remarks do not reflect the views of the Pentagon.

articles.headline: Release of Generic Lipitor Is Delayed
articles.snippet: The settlement of a patent dispute over the blockbuster cholesterol drug will delay the release of generic versions in the United States until 2011.
articles.abstract: The settlement of a patent dispute over the blockbuster cholesterol drug will delay the release of generic versions in the United States until 2011.
articles.lead_paragraph: For people with high cholesterol, the wait for a cheaper version of Lipitor just got longer. Pfizer announced an agreement Wednesday to head off generic competition for its flagship drug until November 2011  up to 20 months later than many analysts had been expecting.

articles.headline: Deals With Iraq Are Set to Bring Oil Giants Back
articles.snippet: Four Western oil companies are in talks with Iraq’s Oil Ministry for no-bid contracts to service the country’s largest fields.
articles.abstract: Four Western oil companies are in talks with Iraq’s Oil Ministry for no-bid contracts to service the country’s largest fields.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Four Western oil companies are in the final stages of negotiations this month on contracts that will return them to Iraq, 36 years after losing their oil concession to nationalization as Saddam Hussein rose to power.
